title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Joe Biden sought to project a return to normality at home and abroad on his first day as president as he secured the confirmation of his top intelligence official and moved to bring the US back into the Paris climate accord.

After being sworn in just before noon and delivering his inaugural address, Mr Biden signed a series of executive actions on Wednesday evening that marked a sharp break with Donald Trump's policies on immigration, the environment and racial justice.

During his first few hours in office, Mr Biden obtained Senate approval for Avril Haines as director of national intelligence, a crucial national security post for his fledgling administration.

Global investors welcomed Mr Biden's arrival in the White House, sending shares to new heights on Thursday. Investors are fixed on the 46th president's promise of $1.9tn in stimulus spending and the jettisoning of isolationist policies pursued by his predecessor.

How do you feel about America's future under Mr Biden? Take our poll.

Read more:

  • Amanda Gorman, the youngest-ever inaugural poet at 22 years old, read “The Hill We Climb”, which reflected on the riot at the Capitol. America's show business royalty returned to the nation's capital on Wednesday to play a starring role at Joe Biden's presidential inauguration.

  • But red lines remain: business leaders have vowed to fight the Biden administration's proposals to raise corporate taxes, tighten regulation and double the federal minimum wage.

  • In energy, the Biden administration is off to a flying start, writes our Energy Source team. Bidenomics has also begun well, writes Martin Sandbu.

  • The FT View is that Mr Biden's inaugural address was a call for a return to US norms and values. Global policymakers, too, are hoping for a reset on trade, tax and aid.

  • Mohamed El-Erian argues that the new president must combine agile political manoeuvring with smart economic policy. (FT, NYT)

In his latest DC Diary video, Kiran Stacey says recent events made the new president's speech calling for unity sound revolutionary as Washington watchers look to see what tone the Democrat leader is aiming to establish at the start of his term of office. (FT)

Sign up for Swamp Notes, our twice-weekly newsletter on the intersection of US politics and power, written by columnists Edward Luce and Rana Foroohar.

Coronavirus digest

  • The US will join global efforts to make Covid-19 vaccines and drugs available around the world, Anthony Fauci said on Thursday. Joe Biden, meanwhile, will sign an executive order today instructing US government agencies to use wartime powers to increase supplies of several items, including coronavirus tests, N95 masks and vaccine syringes.

  • England's lockdown has failed to suppress virus transmission, according to an Imperial College London survey. Hundreds of thousands without a car will struggle to reach vaccination centres, an FT analysis found.

  • China has intensified its battle against a wave of infections — and its blame game with the US. The country's venture capitalist investors have retreated to the safety of favoured sectors during the pandemic, thinning the ranks of tech start-ups.

  • Thailand will charge the country's leading opposition figure under its lèse majesté law after he accused a company owned by King Maha Vajiralongkorn of seeking to profit from distributing Oxford/AstraZeneca's vaccine. (FT)

In the news

China imposes sanctions on Trump officials Beijing has imposed sanctions on several former Trump administration officials, including ex-US secretary of state Mike Pompeo. One of Mr Pompeo's last acts as secretary of state was to call China's repression of Uighurs ‘genocide'. (FT)

Morgan Stanley posts record profit as trading booms Morgan Stanley's earnings jumped 51 per cent in the final three months of 2020, capping a strong results season across Wall Street driven by a boom in trading and fundraising. Due Diligence, our M&A newsletter, listed Wall Street's 2020 winners and losers. (FT)

US online brokerage Tastytrade bought for $1bn British spread betting company IG is buying one of the fastest growing retail investor businesses in the US futures and options market for $1bn. Chicago-based Tastytrade, founded in 2011, has 900,000 subscribers across 190 countries via YouTube and iTunes. (FT)

United Airlines promises more cost cutting United Airlines vowed to step up its cost-cutting efforts after its cash burn rose in the fourth quarter because of interest payments on its mounting debt and the costs of reducing staff. (FT)

Brazil braced for IPO spree An iron ore miner, a crematorium operator and an online furniture seller are among the 41 companies that have announced their intention to debut on São Paulo's B3 exchange, as Brazil's stock market gears up for a rush of flotations in 2021. (FT)

VW hit with EU fines Volkswagen, which includes the Audi, Porsche and Seat brands, will pay more than €100m in fines after narrowly missing strict EU emissions targets in 2020, despite launching its flagship electric vehicle during the year. (FT)

Hindu nationalists rage at Amazon The Indian makers of an Amazon Prime mini-series and a senior company executive are under threat of criminal prosecution after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling Bharatiya Janata party deemed the drama offensive to the country's Hindu majority. (FT)

Historic Tokyo Stock Exchange reshuffle Corporate Japan faces aggressive new guidelines designed to compel a selldown of the country's widely criticised “cross-shareholding” networks — interconnected portfolios of ownership by listed Japanese companies in each other, which protect underperforming managements. (FT)

The day ahead

Biden talks to allies President Joe Biden is expected to speak to Justin Trudeau, Canada's prime minister, the new White House press secretary Jen Psaki, confirmed on Wednesday. She said that other US allies would take precedence in subsequent conversations. (FT)

ECB meeting While the European Central Bank is expected to keep its main monetary policies unchanged on Thursday, Christine Lagarde has signalled that it could expand its main bond-buying programme further if Covid-19 vaccinations are delayed and lockdowns remain in place. (FT)

Economic data US initial jobless claims are forecast to fall to 868,000. The pace rose last week to the highest level since August, with 965,000 applications. US housing starts are expected to have picked up in December. (FT, WSJ)

Earnings Technology groups Intel, which recently appointed a new CEO, and IBM, which this month announced former Trump adviser Gary Cohn would join its board, report earnings on Thursday. (FT)

EU coronavirus summit Leaders will hold a telesummit today to discuss and share “best practices” for how to combat coronavirus and implement vaccination programmes, amid talks of member states restricting borders. (FT)

What else we're reading

The future of America's local newspapers Small regional newspapers, once swimming in cash and an essential service to those living outside New York or San Francisco, have been converted into distressed assets boomeranged among investors for short-term profits. As hedge funds and private equity snap up titles, what does it mean for journalism? (FT)

America's big China question Resetting US-China relations will be near the top of Joe Biden's agenda. FT global China editor James Kynge reviews three books that look at the challenge. Philip Stephens has some ideas as to how the Biden administration should engage with Beijing and outgoing Trump trade chief Robert Lighthizer, defended his record on China when he spoke to Trade Secrets — sign up here. (FT)

Crackdown on Jack Ma's empire gathers pace despite reappearance Jack Ma is back. The relief over his reappearance this week was shortlived, however, write Tom Mitchell in Singapore and Ryan McMorrow and Sun Yu in Beijing. (FT)

Private equity buys the league Sports teams, once local institutions that morphed into global businesses, are entering a new phase as private equity firms seek to profit from the emotional highs sport can provide. But as institutional investors look beyond clubs to governing bodies and competitions, fans risk being alienated. (FT)

Why does Davos Man get it so wrong? Most Davos predictions are worthless. There is no VIP crystal ball. A smarter summit would stick world leaders in the audience while social workers, virologists and reporters recounted recent trends, writes Simon Kuper. (FT)

Navalny's detention test If the Kremlin thought locking up Alexei Navalny would silence Russia's most vocal domestic critic, it was swiftly proved otherwise. Vladimir Putin's iron-like grip on the levers of Russia's skeleton democracy means Mr Navalny's operation will struggle to make electoral inroads. But attempts to sideline the activist have all failed. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Business sends Biden a message, Vestager warns against patchwork tech regulation The FT's Javier Espinoza continues his conversation with the European Commission's competition and digital policy chief, Margrethe Vestager, about the future of big tech regulation on the FT News Briefing podcast. (FT)
